newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resids mostly gain again with crude.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resids mostly gain again with crude.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel prices, shrugging off a tumbling gas market, mostly gained again Thursday in thin trade, boosted by a sharp rally in crude and the prospects for better utility demand soon, sources said.

"Fuel looks pretty strong across the barrel. Crude rallied, and there are a few people looking but not in droves yet because there's no actual demand," said one cash trader, noting fairly mild East Coast temperatures this week.
In New York Harbor, physical one percent firmed 40-50 cents to $15.25 a barrel, with May paper done 35 cents higher at $15.60 on stronger crude, traders said.
NYH June one percent paper sold at $16, steady to up slightly on the day. July paper was quoted at $16.15.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour notionally firmed more than a quarter to about $16, traders said.
New York high sulphurs scored smaller gains, with 2.2 percent up 20 cents to $14.50.
At the U.S. Gulf, three percent gained slightly to $14, while one percent also was modestly higher at $14.75.

New York city gate swing gas prices eased slightly Thursday to the high-$2.50s/mmBtu, or about $16.25 a barrel equivalent. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, also was down slightly to the low-$2.30s/mmBtu, or $14.68 a barrel.
